attributes.comment:
Thank you for providing this opportunity to comment on the idea of creating a CMS-developed and maintained, Application Programming Interface (API)-enabled....National Directory of Healthcare Providers & Services (NDH).

Our brief scan of previous comments indicates you have already received a host of ingenious ideas about WHAT information such a directory ought to consist of, while few commenters devote any attention to HOW it might be assembled -- and maybe more importantly, maintained.

We urge CMS to consider modes of maintenance that enlists the energy and resources of providers themselves to maintain their directory information.

The specific mode we suggest entails inclusion, at the option of care providers, of provider hours of operation, at whatever levels of detail they themselves determine relevant. Existing resources (example: NPPES NPI Registry) identify the WHO, WHAT, & WHERE care providers; those providers can, & are ordinarily are eager to, share WHEN their services can be accessed - much as proprietors of any enterprise are eager to let potential clients or customers know when they are "open for business". It is not simply that operating hours are a "cool feature" that caused Google's business listings give particular attention to this vital data element.

Inasmuch as "consumers use provider directories and online searches more than any other resource" to locate and engage with health treatment providers, enabling those providers to include their "normal" operating hours information themselves - along with "special" days/hours (holidays, evening hours, etc), perhaps for a premium fee (and that "fee" might well be paid in the form of their review & updating of their other directory information, as well as or in lieu of money) - might open the possibility that CMS's project could incorporate a source of revenue for sustaining the directory's content maintenance imperative, a function your introductory remarks points out is often fatally neglected in initiatives such as this.

Obviously numerous technical challenges and process decisions would need to be made to incorporate any "hours of operation" "concession" like the one we have sketched here. We're confident CMS would find that addressing those technical hurdles would be well worth the exertion as part of any directory initiative it pursues.

Please contact us regarding clarification of any points we have made here.
